ratings.comment: Professor's teaching was not it for me. His content presentation is chaotic. He throws random examples at you & fails to build new knowledge on top of existing, presents concepts "in a vacuum". Poor verbal explanation skills. HOWEVER, the grading criteria is clear and he's always accessible outside class. Avoid if you want to actually learn things

Professor Gurevich is a great professor who is passionate about maths. Lectures are mostly clear though can be hard to follow at times. Expect to spend a lot of time on homework but he gives many hints if not outright answers in recorded Zoom meetings. You can learn nothing and still get an A, but if you put in the work you can learn a lot.

Gurevich is a good person, and very passionate about math. His class will only be as good as you make it. If you are not self-motivated, you'll likely ChatGPT your way through HW and quizzes, not attend lecture, and learn nothing (but get an A/B). Meet with him, attend the early morning zooms, and he will grow on you, and you'll learn lots of math.

Professor Gurevitch is one of the best professors I've had. Aside from his knowledge, his enthusiasm and dedication to his students is very evident. He spends hours outside of class explaining the homeworks and making himself available to students to talk about the class content. The class isn't easy, but extremely rewarding and you'll learn a lot.

Shamgar has a lot to offer for those who want to go further into math, especially if you like axiomatic math like LA/AA.  Expect to spend a decent amount of time on HW.  He practically gives answers over Zoom, but writing proofs down adequately still takes time.  Also he uploaded the text onto Canvas so he's goated

Not sure why there are so many negative reviews here. I found his presentation of Linear Algebra clear, well-structured, and helpful for understanding the concepts involved. He also clearly knows and cares a lot about the math. He is an easy grader; I think almost everyone in the class got an A.

Shamgar was the first time a professor made me question the value of college. If the students are being honest with themselves, they know that they barely learned anything from him and class time was often wasted. You'll enjoy that it's an easy A, but if value getting something out of the class more than your grade you'll find his teaching sad.
Hard lectures but homework and exams are easy.
Not a great lecturer, but Shamgar makes it very clear what he expects you to know coming into any quiz or exam. Practice tests mirror the actual ones almost exactly. Overall, a good experience.

He comes off as rude to students occasionally, his handwriting is very hard to read, and his notes are written on crumpled loose pieces of notebook paper, but he clearly is knowledgeable and uniquely hilarious. Not a great professor, but I think everyone who has a chance should experience his lectures.

Shamgar can come off as oblivious and arrogant at first, but he is an incredibly knowledgeable, qualified, and caring individual. His explanation of concepts is clear, but the portrayal of the explanation is difficult (illegible writing + language). Despite being available for office hours, he never follows the schedule so expect to lose 45 min.

Avoid Shamgar at all costs: -Handwriting during lectures is illegible -Does not explain material clearly at all -Does not explain Linear Algebra material required for a LA class (Math 341 taken) -Makes students wait 45 mins for a SCHEDULED appointment (He told you 4:00? You won't get to see him until 4:30-4:45) -You will learn very very little

Clearly smart and cares for showing thorough explanations on the material before testing. But he is arrogant during student presentations, and turns into a different person when he doesn't get his way (so the TA quit). Releases challenging HWs 4 days before quiz when he promises 14. If he just works through those things, he is absolutely worth it.

You won't find a professor that is willing to stay hours past his office hours to work with students. If you can get past some communication barriers, he is a hilarious guy. He is an easy grader and gives his finals and midterms out as study guides before the exam.

Pretty easy class, low workload. Although he is not good at teaching and you don't learn much. If you need to take this class as a requirement for another class and want a relatively easy class, I would recommend Gurevich(it will be boring though). Do not take this class for fun or if you want to learn, it's a waste of time.

Worst professor I've seen. We have no canvas page and no syllabus, and now our TA has quit. He has no plan at all for his lectures, he does not understand the prerequisite for the course, and he cannot even speak English well. Like someone has mentioned, it's almost been half of the semester, we barely have learnt anything. DO NOT TAKE HIS COURSE!
worst professor I have seen. We don't have Canvas even syllabus, and TA quit in the half of the semester. Don't take the class.

lol. You have a 5050 chance of getting him to answer your question in office hours. Sometimes he was very eager to help, other times he was cold and straight up said he wouldn't answer questions. Class moves kind of slow and practice exams are fairly similar to actual exams. Quiz questions are similar to homework questions.

I would avoid him. I found his lectures themselves pretty clear, and he basically give answers to his exams(writing what we need for proofs, same Q's as practice exam).  but we barely covered anything. We only touched on eigenvalsvectors at the end of the semester. He is very rude about questions and had extra lectures multiple times a week.

Said hw was completion, actually graded on correctness. Said quizzes were only definitions, were actually on tough questions and proofs. Didn't get through material quickly enough so he required weekly evening lectures. Lectures were disorganized and confusing. Tests were very straightforward and not tough as long as you go to both reviews

Worst professor I've had. Every aspect of his class is disorganized. Impossible to follow his lectures. Holds additional weekly evening lectures. Handwriting is horrible, and you can't even understand what he's saying most of the time. The only learning happens during discussion. Repeats useless example after useless example.
We are still on chapter 1.1 for half the semester. I haven't learned a thing from him. He thought he is being funny but, to me, it is helpless.
As easy as a math class can get. First part of the class is literally multiplying and simplifying matrices. Practice tests very similar to midterms and final.

Easy professor does not mean he is a good professor. He rarely explain deep or hard concepts (which are important  actually) well and simply confuse everyone.  Condescending in the class. Feels that I have not learned anything except passing the exams with good grades. If you take math seriously or pursue a major in computer science.  Avoid him.

Easy professor, the midterm and final were very similar to the reviews he gave.  He will try to elaborate on more complicated topics to improve understanding (which often just confuses everyone) but only tests on the most important, basic concepts.
Amazing professor!  Did everything possible to help students succeed.  Lectures always very interesting.  Course constructed in a clear way.

Professor Gurevich teach the students in a friendly way. He likes you to think on the meaning and motivations for mathematical notions and theorems. The tests and grading are fair. The TA Jon Lima did a very good job.
This was a great course. Professor care very much for the understanding of the students, and spend a lot of time with them. I enjoyed the course very much.

Shamgar is a great professor, while his lectures can be a little confusing during, you are usually able to figure out what happened afterward.  His TA of choice is Jon Lima and together it is my opinion that they are the best team at Madison.  It is extremely hard to not get an A in this class and virtually impossible to get below a B.  Take it!
Awesome professor. Really prepares you for exams.  Repeats concepts in lecture a lot.  Funny. I never used the book, but I always went to class. His practice exams are EXACTLY like the tests.

Shamgar is the man. He's quite funny and lays out quite clearly what will be on the exam a few days prior to it. His lectures are pretty hard to follow in my opinion,  but he's open to questions. Take him if you have the chance.

While the tests were easy (M/C) and mirrored the practice exams, homework contained numerous errors - including incorrect definitions of mathematical terms. Prof. Gurevich repeated himself in lecture for weeks, so not many topics were introduced. Engaging Prof during "extra" evening lectures, though. Easy A+ & easy to skip, but I didn't learn much.

Shamgar's lectures are a little bit hard to understand and he keeps repeating everything he says during the lectures. The class is not hard at all. My midterm and final were multiple choice and they were very similar to the practise exams. It really easy to get a A, if you just attend your discussion and skip most of your lectures.
Goes out of his way to help students and prepares you well for his exams. He goes through plenty of examples and the questions are similar to the ones he does in class.
GREAT professor!!Very helpful and treating students like friends.
